text: feeling well today, and so you pray for Norma Jean, and then pray for Miss Mauna as well. I don't know, she's normally here, and so she's not here this evening. We'll follow up and see if she's doing well, but I would like for you to pray for Miss Mauna as well, and we're thankful to the Lord for the privilege of prayer. The book of Ephesians this evening, Ephesians chapter number six, and we have now for a number of weeks here on Wednesday evenings have had the opportunity to study this subject matter of doing what we ought to do. Doing what we ought to do, and as we've had this opportunity to study these passages of scripture in the New Testament that speak about the things that we ought to do, we understand that God has given us this truth, and we ought to apply it in our lives. Knowing what we ought to do doesn't immediately make it the case that we do what we ought to do, and so as we study through these things, we wanna be challenged and allow the Lord to have his will and way in our lives. I find it fascinating and insightful to read Paul's request for prayer as it's recorded here in Ephesians chapter number six. Previously in this book as he's writing to this church that God allowed him to have an opportunity to minister to these precious souls for a number of years, and the ministry there and the opportunity to be able to influence them, and he encouraged them previously in the book of Ephesians by revealing to them how he was praying for them, and he doesn't just simply say I'm praying for you, but he explains to them on two separate occasions here in the book of Ephesians how specifically he is praying for them, and I'm sure that was of great encouragement to the believers when they received this letter and they understood how the apostle Paul was praying for them. Now as we come to the last part of the chapter of the book in Ephesians six verses 19 and 20, Paul makes a request for prayer, and again, it's fascinating and insightful as you read his request that is given to the believers at Ephesus. Notice in verse 19, he says, and for me. Now he mentions in verse 18 about prayer and the subject is dealing with praying for all the saints, but then in verse 19, he says, and for me, and so he's gonna deal with the specific prayer request that he is submitting, if you will, to the believers at the church at Ephesus. Notice as we think about this that there are times in which we submit prayer requests. We have a prayer bulletin weekly, and Holly updates that, and sometimes you give a prayer request verbally in the service as we have the concluding part of our service for prayer, and you say would you pray for so on and so forth, and whatever that request is, you can make the request in writing, you can send an email, you can send a text, and you give that request, and we understand, and now Paul, as he's writing to these believers in Ephesus here in Ephesians 6, he says, and for me in verse 19, so he's going to give them a specific personal request for prayer, that utterance may be given unto me that I may open my mouth boldly to make known the mystery of the gospel. So in verse number 19, he gives the truth with regard to what he's asking prayer for, and he says that utterance may be given unto me, and then notice that I may open my mouth boldly, but not just to say anything, not just to have boldness to speak on whatever platform that he's desiring, whatever soapbox, if you will, that he's desiring to speak on, whatever cause it is that he's trying to promote, no, that I may open my mouth boldly for what purpose to make known the mystery of the gospel. Notice in verse 20, for which I am an ambassador in bonds, that therein I may speak boldly, and then here's the statement, as I ought to speak. And so we find that the apostle Paul has this understanding that he ought to speak the gospel with boldness. I've titled the message tonight, if you're taking notes, that we ought to proclaim the gospel. We ought to proclaim the gospel. As I consider just the opening thoughts of Paul making this request to these believers in Ephesus and the way in which I stated that it's both fascinating and insightful to read how Paul is praying for them, but also how he requests prayer, it leads me to a place of being mindful of the fact that we ought to analyze our prayer list. We ought to analyze what it is that we're praying for. What significance of things are we praying for? What plane, if you will, are there more temporally focused or eternally focused? And as we analyze our prayer list, and also not only analyzing our prayer list, but reviewing what we request prayer for, we find that there really is anything that Paul could have submitted here to the church at Ephesus for prayer, but he asks specifically that he would be given, that they would pray that he would be given this boldness to be able to speak the gospel. Why? Because he knows that he ought to be speaking the gospel. Now, this is always an interesting passage of scripture to me here in Ephesians 6, verses 19 and 20, because honestly, as I read the New Testament, and as I analyze the life of the Apostle Paul, he is a man that is probably the most active proclaimer of the gospel in the New Testament. He's the one that's traveling from place to place on these missionary journeys, and he's proclaiming the gospel, he's making known Christ, he's sent over to Athens in order to get some rest, if you will, because of all the things that have transpired, and there, as he sees a city that's wholly given to idolatry, what does he do? He's stirred, and he goes, and he seeks to make Christ known to them, and we find that Paul was extremely active. In fact, think about what Paul says in Acts chapter number 20 as he's writing or speaking to these leaders of the church at Ephesus. In Acts chapter number 20, he's had the leaders of the church at Ephesus meet him as he's on his way to Jerusalem, and as they meet there in Acts chapter number 20, he imparts to them some important things. We won't look at the entirety. We're gonna zero in on one particular statement that he makes with regard to the subject this evening of we ought to proclaim the gospel, and notice what he says in verse number 31. Therefore, watch and remember, and so there's something that Paul did that he's calling to their remembrance that by the space of three years, I ceased not to warn everyone night and day with tears. So Paul, as we look in Acts chapter 20, his testimony is such, especially with the testimony that he has with the believers in Ephesus, that he ceased not to warn for a period of three years. What is the warning? Well, it's giving the gospel. He's warning them about judgment to come and about the need to trust Christ, and he says that he was doing it with tears. Notice he says night and day with tears. So the apostle Paul had an understanding. His understanding was that he ought to speak boldly the gospel. Why is it, what is it that he understood about God and about God's plan that led him to having this belief that he ought to speak the gospel, to proclaim the gospel with boldness? Well, let me give you just a couple of thoughts this evening. If you're taking notes, number one, I believe the apostle Paul understood the command of Christ, the command of Christ. You say, yeah, we know this. We can rehearse the great commission. Can I say this? And with all sincerity, knowing the great commission isn't the same as fulfilling the great commission, amen? Knowing, again, what I said, as we've looked at this series here on Wednesday night, knowing what we ought to do doesn't mean we're actually doing what we ought to do. And so the ability for us to quote the great commission, to know the places within God's word where the great commission is contained does not mean that we personally are actively speaking, proclaiming the gospel as we ought to be. We find that there's, of course, the gospel, the great commission is given in each book of the gospels, Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. It's given in the book of Acts as well. Probably the simplest form, the one that is most widely memorized is Mark 16 and 15, and we're to preach the gospel to every creature. And we understand that. We understand this evening the importance of that portion of scripture and the simplicity with regard to what Jesus says there. And of course, he says it in different ways in each of the gospels as is recorded for us, but he says that we're to go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature. Now, going into all the world starts by just going across the street. Is it not true? I was speaking with someone yesterday that was a freshman there at the college. In fact, as we were in the hotel and I was down and had some breakfast and there weren't too many people down there and a young man comes and he asked if the seat was available and he sat there and he opened his Bible and so I kind of assumed that maybe he was preparing to go to the college because he sat down and opened his Bible and he was of that age and I inquired and sure enough he's going to be studying and he began to ask me questions and what have you and I was sharing with him and I can't give you all the details, it would take too long, but the reality is one of the statements that I made to him is that where we have the privilege of ministering here in Northern Virginia that literally the world is in our backyard and we see that, we understand that, we see how that the opportunities are before us and truly sharing the gospel, proclaiming the gospel begins by simply taking that step and engaging with an individual. You don't have to cross an ocean, you don't have to get on an airplane or a boat in order to go and proclaim the gospel to someone. Acts 1.8, but you shall receive power after that the Holy Ghost has come upon you and you shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, Judea, Samaria, the uttermost part of the earth and remember the disciple said this, we are his witnesses. We have it, that portion of Acts 5 is on the wall above our track rack to remind us that we are his witnesses and if we have the truth and I believe we do, listen, if I didn't think it was true, I'd just go do something different, right, but I believe it's true and we have it and therefore we ought to give it. I want you to consider the life of Paul though when we consider the command of Christ, notice if you will over in Acts 26. And he said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest. But then notice verse 16, but rise and stand upon thy feet for I have appeared unto thee for this purpose, to make thee a minister and a witness both of these things which thou hast seen and of those things in the which I will appear unto thee, delivering thee from the people and from the Gentiles unto whom now I send thee to open their eyes and to turn them from darkness to light and from the power of Satan unto God that they may receive forgiveness of sins and inheritance among them, which are sanctified by faith that is in me. Isn't that a great mission that God communicated to the Apostle Paul at this time in his life, he saw, he's just converted, he says, who art thou Lord? What wilt thou have me to do? And we find that Jesus gives him this revelation, he tells him that he's gonna send him as a witness of these things. He tells them that as he goes and he preaches, it's going to be so that their eyes, that they could be turned from darkness to light, from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins. This is what we get to do when we proclaim the gospel, this is what we're doing, we're giving somebody the greatest news. I understand that sometimes they don't receive it that way, but Paul understood this, he understood the command of Christ. I want you to notice, I stopped reading in verse 18, but I want you to look at what it says in Acts 26, in verse 19, look at what Paul says, whereupon, O King Agrippa, notice what he says, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision. Paul considered this thought and this practice of proclaiming the gospel a matter of obedience, obedience to Christ, and he says to Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision. He says it this way to the church in Corinth in 1 Corinthians chapter nine, he's speaking to them about the privilege that he has to be involved in the gospel ministry, and he says this in 1 Corinthians nine in verse 16, for though I preach the gospel, I have nothing to glory of, for necessity is laid upon me, yea, woe is unto me if I preach not the gospel. And he says in verse 23, and this I do for the gospel's sake that I might be partaker thereof with you. I think about the apostle Paul and a man that surrendered and yielded to proclaiming the gospel, but yet a man that when he submits a request for prayer to the church at Ephesus, what is it that he requests prayer for?
